SEARCH
Package com.oblong.jelly

Interface Hose

All Known Implementing Classes:
FilteredHose, MemHose, NetHose
@NotThreadSafe public interface Hose
Interface for bidirectional communication with a pool.

Using a PoolServer as a factory, or directly via Pool.participate(String) (or any of its overloads), you can obtain an instance of this class, which provides you with a bidirectional protein exchange channel with a concrete pool, as well as with some other methods to manipulate the pool's state and obtain associated metadata.

A Hose maintains some local state, relevant to the client using it. Most notably, an index which denotes the position on the pool's protein stream. This position (returned by index()) is used implicitly by protein retrieval methods that do not specify an explicit position in the stream.

A second piece of local state is a free form name that client code can assign, and mutate at any time. This name can be used in the client side in any way you see fit, without affecting in any way the communications with the server.

And, finally, there's of course the data structures involved in the network connection.

The presence of mutable state, coupled with the fact that Hose instances use no built-in synchronization mechanisms, makes them non-thread-safe.

It is also important to keep in mind that the network resources consumed by a Hose should be explicitly released (using withdraw()), to ensure their proper and timely management.

Regarding error reporting, this interface follows the usual policy with pool errors in jelly: methods have a throws PoolException clause and will throw all the appropriate subtypes, that can be caught specifically if you so desire (see discussion here).

  • Method Details

    • version

      int version()
      The network protocol used to communicate with the pool server is versioned. This method gives you access to the version of the network protocol used by this hose.

    • name

      String name()
      This Hose's name. This is a local name that bears no relation to the pool URI, except for the fact that it's initialized to that value as a default. You can however modify the hose's name without affecting in any way the pool it's connected to.

    • setName

      void setName(String n)
      Modifies the local name of this Hose. Changing this name in no way modifies the underlying connection.

    • poolAddress

      PoolAddress poolAddress()
      The address of the pool this Hose is (or was) connected to.

    • isConnected

      boolean isConnected()
      Whether the connection with the target pool is still alive.

      This will return false if, for instance, you've called withdraw() before.

    • withdraw

      void withdraw()
      Closes the connection with the target pool, releasing all associated resources. This method is idempotent.

      After calling this method, any other operation involving the remote end of the connection will fail with a InOutException.

      As stressed before, explicitly calling this method in client code is of the essence for correct resource management (you can think of Hose instances as, say, Socket instances in that regard). A usage pattern ensuring proper resource management could be: 

          Hose hose = null;
    try {
       hose = Pool.participate("tcp://imladris/brandywine");
       playWithThisHose(hose);
    } catch (PoolException e) {
       // ...
    } finally {
       if (hose != null) {
         hose.withdraw();
         hose = null;
       }
    }
      and variants thereof.

    • index

      long index()
      Every Hose maintains, locally, a pointer or index into the pool's protein stream. This pointer works as an implicit parameter for protein retrieval methods that don't specify an index among its parameters.

    • newestIndex

      long newestIndex() throws PoolException
      Asks the server for the index of the last deposited protein so far.

      Calling this method does not modify this Hose's index.

      Throws:
      PoolException

    • oldestIndex

      long oldestIndex() throws PoolException
      Asks the server for the index of the first available protein.

      The index sequence increases monotonically, so oldestIndex() will always be less than or equal to newestIndex().

      Calling this method does not modify this Hose's index.

      Throws:
      PoolException

    • seekTo

      void seekTo(long index)
      Sets the local value of the current index to the given value.

      There's no communication with the server, and the value of the current index is set unconditionally to the provided one.

    • seekBy

      void seekBy(long offset)
      Shifts the local value of the current index by the given offset.

      There's no communication with the server, and the value of the current index is modified unconditionally.

    • toLast

      void toLast() throws PoolException
      Sets the local index to that of the very newest protein in the pool. That is, calling current() immediately after this method will return the latest deposited protein (barring intervening deposits by this or other processes).
      Throws:
      PoolException

    • runOut

      void runOut() throws PoolException
      Sets the local index pointing just past the end of the pool, so that a call to next(com.oblong.jelly.Slaw...) will wait, returning the next protein deposited by another participant.
      Throws:
      PoolException

    • rewind

      void rewind() throws PoolException
      Sets the local index to that of the first protein in the pool. That is, calling current() immediately after this method will return the first available protein in the pool.
      Throws:
      PoolException

    • metadata

      PoolMetadata metadata() throws PoolException
      Returns generic metadata about the pool we're connected to.
      Throws:
      PoolException

    • deposit

      Protein deposit(Protein p) throws PoolException
      Tries to deposit the give protein at the end of the pool.

      If the operation succeeds, the returned protein will be the same as p cum Slaw, but its timestamp and index will correspond to those reported by the server. Remember that Protein instances are immutable, so that p won't (can't) be modified.

      Since any error during the deposit will be reported by throwing a PoolException, you're guaranteed that the returned Protein will always be non-null. If you're not interested in the index or timestamp of the deposited protein, you can just ignore that return value. 

          try {
      Protein dep = hose.deposit(p);
      System.out.println("Deposited with index " + dep.index()
                          + " and stamp " + dep.timestamp());
      letsMoveOn();
   } catch (PoolException e) {
      System.out.println("Ooops: " + e.getMessage());
   }

      Note that the index and timestamp of p are ignored, as is the local index of the Hose.

      Throws:
      PoolException

    • nth

      Protein nth(long index) throws PoolException
      Fetches the protein located at the given index value.

      Calling this method does not modify the local index and, if the invocation succeeds, the return value is guaranteed to be non-null.

      Throws:
      PoolException - If no protein with the requested index exists, the PoolException will be of type NoSuchProteinException. Other kinds, possibly related to communication problems or conditions encountered by the pool server, may also arise.
      See Also:
      • nth(long, boolean, boolean, boolean)

    • nth

      Protein nth(long index, boolean descrips, boolean ingests, boolean data) throws PoolException
      Partially fetches the protein located at the given index. The boolean flags indicate whether the different components of the protein should be fetched. Setting any of them to false will make the returned protein to miss them, possibly resulting in less data across the network.

      Calling nth(i, true, true, true) is equivalent to a plain nth(i) call.

      Throws:
      PoolException - If no protein with the requested index exists, the PoolException will be of type NoSuchProteinException. Other kinds, possibly related to communication problems or conditions encountered by the pool server, may also arise.

    • range

      List<Protein> range(long from, long to) throws PoolException
      Retrieves all available proteins with the index the [from, to) interval. If any of the requested indexes is not present in the pool, the protein is just omitted from the returned list, so it might well be that the its length is less that (to - from) (but it will never be greater).

      The return value is never null: if no protein in the requested range is found, an empty list is returned.

      In general, this method is not equivalent to calling nth(long) in a loop because the data will be fetched in a single request to the pool, saving network bandwidth (when the network is involved, of course).

      Throws:
      PoolException

    • metadata

      ProteinMetadata metadata(MetadataRequest req) throws PoolException
      Retrieves metadata about a given protein. The protein is described by its index, stored in req, which also describes the pieces of metadata to be fetched.
      Throws:
      PoolException - If no protein with the requested index exists, the PoolException will be of type NoSuchProteinException. Other kinds, possibly related to communication problems or conditions encountered by the pool server, may also arise.
      See Also:
      • ProteinMetadata
      • MetadataRequest

    • metadata

      List<ProteinMetadata> metadata(MetadataRequest... reqs) throws PoolException
      Performs, in a single operation, a bunch of metadata requests.

      Since all the requests are sent in one batch, using this method (instead of repeated calls to metadata(MetadataRequest) you'll save network traffic for remote pools.

      A second difference is that unfulfilled requests will not cause an error; instead, the corresponding metadata will be omitted from the returned list. Therefore, in general, metadata(reqs).size() invalid input: '<'= reqs.length.

      Throws:
      PoolException

    • current

      Protein current() throws PoolException
      Retrieves the Protein located at the current value of the index.

      Calling this method does not modify the local index and, if the invocation succeeds, the return value is guaranteed to be non-null. Successive calls to current will return the same protein over and over unless and until the pool fills up and wraps around, but note that each one will imply a connection to the server and could still fail.

      Throws:
      PoolException - Since the Hose's index can be set to arbitrary values on the client side (and, moreover, proteins in the pool can be overwritten when no space is left in it), a possible outcome of this method is a NoSuchProteinException. All other kinds of PoolException describing problems when talking with a pool server can also occur.

    • next

      Protein next(Slaw... descrips) throws PoolException
      Looks for the next protein in the pool whose descrips match the given ones.

      The search will start at the current index, and proceed forward until a protein matching (see below) the given descrips is found, or no more proteins are available, in which case a PoolException with kind PoolException.Kind.NO_SUCH_PROTEIN (and, therefore, type NoSuchProteinException) will be thrown.

      If descrips is empty, any protein will match. Otherwise, matching is checked using Protein.matches(com.oblong.jelly.Slaw...) on incoming proteins (although, for remote servers, that check can and will be performed on the server side). Remember that matching can occurr only on descrips which are lists.

      Throws:
      PoolException

    • awaitNext

      Protein awaitNext(long period, TimeUnit unit) throws PoolException, TimeoutException
      Like next(com.oblong.jelly.Slaw...), but blocking (with a timeout) if no proteins are available.

      Whe a next protein is already available, this method behaves just like next. Otherwise, it will wait for a new protein to appear in the pool (with an index equal or greater than the current one) for the specified amount of time.

      When period is 0, this method behaves like next(com.oblong.jelly.Slaw...) (i.e., it doesn't wait), while if period is negative, it behaves like awaitNext() (i.e., it waits forever).

      Note that, if you have moved forward the local index past the end of the pool (i.e., to a value greater than newestIndex() + 1, it may be the case that more than one protein must be added to the pool by other participants before this call returns.

      A failure to retrieve a protein because the timeout expires is reported by throwing a TimeoutException (which is not a PoolException). A typical usage pattern is thus: 

         try {
       handleProtein(pool.waitNext(period, TimeUnit.SECONDS));
   } catch (TimeoutException e) {
       handleTimeout();
   } catch (PoolException e) {
       handleProtocolError();
   }
      Throws:
      PoolException
      TimeoutException

    • awaitNext

      Protein awaitNext() throws PoolException
      Like next(com.oblong.jelly.Slaw...), but blocking indefinitely if no proteins are available.

      This method will return only when a protein is available, or an error accessing the server occurs. In the latter case, no attempts to regain communication with the server is made, and the error is reporting by throwing a PoolException of the appropriate type.

      Throws:
      PoolException

    • previous

      Protein previous(Slaw... descrips) throws PoolException
      Retrieves the next Protein in the pool with index strictly less than this Hose's local index, and decreases the latter.

      If the list of descrips is not empty, the given protein must also match it, according to the predicate Protein.matches(com.oblong.jelly.Slaw...).

      If there are no proteins with an index lesser than the current local index, a NoSuchProteinException is thrown, and the local index is not modified.

      Since indexes in a pool are assigned in a strictly increasing sequence, there's no possibility of waiting for a previous protein.

      Successive calls to previous will allow you to move sequentially through the protein stream, back to its beginning. After each successful call to previous, the local hose index will be equal to that of the returned protein.

      Throws:
      PoolException

    • dup

      Hose dup() throws PoolException
      Creates a new connection to the same pool, and sets the new hose's index to this instance's value. The returned value also inherits this hose's name and is always connected.
      Throws:
      PoolException

    • dupAndClose

      Hose dupAndClose() throws PoolException
      Like dup(), but closes this hose after transferring its connection to the returned one.
      Throws:
      PoolException

    • closeConnectionAbruptly

      void closeConnectionAbruptly()
      NOTE: This is useful only for debugging/testing purposes, for simulating connection going down. It is a public method, because it is used by external automatic-testing code. Closes socket abrutply, without any prior "withdraw"-style communication. Exempt from threadChecker, since it is used for testing and the intent is abrupt disconnection, without going through "official" channels - simulating network connectivity loss.
